title: This is a minimalist
Hello World example
a
http://stackoverflow.com/documentation/documentation/258/getting-started-with-documentation/11157
that uses only the most basic Android tools.

inline_content.Text: that uses only the most basic Android tools.

title: This example assumes Linux. You may have to adjust the syntax for your own platform.

inline_content.Text: This example assumes Linux. You may have to adjust the syntax for your own platform.

title: Install additional packages using the SDK manager.

inline_content.Text: Install additional packages using the SDK manager.

title:
Don't use `android update sdk --no-ui` as instructed in the bundled Readme.txt;
it downloads some 30 GB of unnecessary files.
Instead use the interactive SDK manager `android sdk`
to get the recommended minimum of packages.

content_resolved.code:
Don't use `android update sdk --no-ui` as instructed in the bundled Readme.txt;
it downloads some 30 GB of unnecessary files.
Instead use the interactive SDK manager `android sdk`
to get the recommended minimum of packages.

title: Append the following JDK and SDK directories to your execution PATH. This is optional, but the instructions below assume it.

inline_content.Text: Append the following JDK and SDK directories to your execution PATH. This is optional, but the instructions below assume it.

title:
* JDK/bin
* SDK/platform-tools
* SDK/tools
* SDK/build-tools/LATEST *(as installed in step 1)*

content_resolved.code:
* JDK/bin
* SDK/platform-tools
* SDK/tools
* SDK/build-tools/LATEST *(as installed in step 1)*

title:
Use the interactive AVD Manager (`android avd`).
You might have to fiddle a bit and search for advice;
the [on-site instructions][createAVD] aren't always helpful.

(You can also use your own device)

content_resolved.code:
Use the interactive AVD Manager (`android avd`).
You might have to fiddle a bit and search for advice;
the [on-site instructions][createAVD] aren't always helpful.

(You can also use your own device)

title: If the device screen appears to be locked, then swipe to unlock it.

inline_content.Text: If the device screen appears to be locked, then swipe to unlock it.

title: Leave it running while you code the app.

inline_content.Text: Leave it running while you code the app.

title: Change to an empty working directory.

inline_content.Text: Change to an empty working directory.

title:
<?xml version='1.0'?>
<manifest xmlns:a='http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android'
 package='dom.domain' a:versionCode='0' a:versionName='0'>
    <application a:label='Saying hello'>
        <activity a:name='dom.domain.SayingHello'>
             <intent-filter>
                <category a:name='android.intent.category.LAUNCHER'/>
                <action a:name='android.intent.action.MAIN'/>
                </intent-filter>
            </activity>
        </application>
    </manifest>

content_resolved.code:
<?xml version='1.0'?>
<manifest xmlns:a='http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android'
 package='dom.domain' a:versionCode='0' a:versionName='0'>
    <application a:label='Saying hello'>
        <activity a:name='dom.domain.SayingHello'>
             <intent-filter>
                <category a:name='android.intent.category.LAUNCHER'/>
                <action a:name='android.intent.action.MAIN'/>
                </intent-filter>
            </activity>
        </application>
    </manifest>

title: Make a sub-directory for the declared resources:

inline_content.Text: Make a sub-directory for the declared resources:

title: Generate the source for the resource declarations.

inline_content.Text: Generate the source for the resource declarations.

title:
Substitute here the correct path to your **SDK**,
and the installed **API** to build against (e.g. "android-23"):

content_resolved.code:
Substitute here the correct path to your **SDK**,
and the installed **API** to build against (e.g. "android-23"):

title:
aapt package -f \
  -I SDK/platforms/android-API/android.jar \
  -J src -m \
  -M AndroidManifest.xml -S res -v

content_resolved.code:
aapt package -f \
  -I SDK/platforms/android-API/android.jar \
  -J src -m \
  -M AndroidManifest.xml -S res -v

title:
Resource declarations (described further below) are actually optional.
Meantime the above call does nothing if res/ is still empty.

content_resolved.code:
Resource declarations (described further below) are actually optional.
Meantime the above call does nothing if res/ is still empty.

title: Compile the source code to Java bytecode (.java → .class):

inline_content.Text: Compile the source code to Java bytecode (.java → .class):

title: Translate the bytecode from Java to Android (.class → .dex):

inline_content.Text: Translate the bytecode from Java to Android (.class → .dex):

title: Android bytecode used to be called "Dalvik executable code", and so "dex".

content_resolved.code: Android bytecode used to be called "Dalvik executable code", and so "dex".

title:
You could replace steps 11 and 12 with a single call to Jack if you like;
it can compile directly from Java source (.java → .dex).
But there are advantages to compiling with `javac`.
It's a better known, better documented and more widely applicable tool.

content_resolved.code:
You could replace steps 11 and 12 with a single call to Jack if you like;
it can compile directly from Java source (.java → .dex).
But there are advantages to compiling with `javac`.
It's a better known, better documented and more widely applicable tool.

title: Package up the resource files, including the manifest:

inline_content.Text: Package up the resource files, including the manifest:

title:
aapt package -f \
  -F app.apkPart \
  -I SDK/platforms/android-API/android.jar \
  -M AndroidManifest.xml -S res -v

content_resolved.code:
aapt package -f \
  -F app.apkPart \
  -I SDK/platforms/android-API/android.jar \
  -M AndroidManifest.xml -S res -v

title: That results in a partial APK file (Android application package).

content_resolved.code: That results in a partial APK file (Android application package).

title: Make the full APK using the
ApkBuilder
c
tool:

inline_content.Text: Make the full APK using the

title:
java -classpath SDK/tools/lib/sdklib.jar \
  com.android.sdklib.build.ApkBuilderMain \
  app.apkUnalign \
  -d -f classes.dex -v -z app.apkPart

content_resolved.code:
java -classpath SDK/tools/lib/sdklib.jar \
  com.android.sdklib.build.ApkBuilderMain \
  app.apkUnalign \
  -d -f classes.dex -v -z app.apkPart

title:
It warns, "THIS TOOL IS DEPRECATED.  See --help for more information."
If `--help` fails with an `ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException`,
then instead pass no arguments:

content_resolved.code:
It warns, "THIS TOOL IS DEPRECATED.  See --help for more information."
If `--help` fails with an `ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException`,
then instead pass no arguments:

title:
It explains that the CLI (`ApkBuilderMain`) is deprecated
in favour of directly calling the Java API (`ApkBuilder`).
(If you know how to do that from the command line, please update this example.)

content_resolved.code:
It explains that the CLI (`ApkBuilderMain`) is deprecated
in favour of directly calling the Java API (`ApkBuilder`).
(If you know how to do that from the command line, please update this example.)

title: It should run and say hello.

title: That’s all. That’s what it takes to say hello using the basic Android tools.

inline_content.Text: That’s all. That’s what it takes to say hello using the basic Android tools.

title: This section is optional. Resource declarations aren’t required for a simple “hello world” app. If they aren’t required for your app either, then you could streamline the build somewhat by omitting step 10, and removing the reference to the res/ directory from step 13.

inline_content.Text: This section is optional. Resource declarations aren’t required for a simple “hello world” app. If they aren’t required for your app either, then you could streamline the build somewhat by omitting step 10, and removing the reference to the res/ directory from step 13.
